symptoms_tips.tip: It sounds like you have a fever. Make sure to stay hydrated and rest. If your fever persists, please consult a doctor.
symptoms_tips.food: Drink plenty of fluids like water, herbal teas, or clear broths. Eat light foods like bananas, rice, applesauce, and toast (BRAT diet). Avoid heavy or spicy meals.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter fever reducers like acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil/Motrin) may help. Follow dosage instructions carefully.

symptoms_tips.tip: For headaches, try to rest in a quiet, dark room. Stay hydrated and consider over-the-counter pain relief.
symptoms_tips.food: Drink water or non-caffeinated beverages to stay hydrated. Eating magnesium-rich foods like spinach, nuts, and whole grains may also help.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil/Motrin) can provide relief. Avoid excessive caffeine intake.

symptoms_tips.tip: If you have a cough, it may be helpful to stay hydrated and use a humidifier. Avoid irritants like smoke or strong odors.
symptoms_tips.food: Warm liquids like herbal teas with honey or clear broths can soothe your throat. Avoid dairy products if they increase mucus production.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Consider over-the-counter cough suppressants or expectorants as directed. Consult a healthcare provider for persistent or severe coughs.

symptoms_tips.tip: To alleviate nausea, try eating small, frequent meals and avoid greasy or spicy foods. Resting in a comfortable position may also help.
symptoms_tips.food: Eat bland foods like crackers, toast, or bananas. Ginger in various forms (ginger tea, ginger ale) is known to help settle the stomach.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter medications like dimenhydrinate (Dramamine) or meclizine (Bonine) can help relieve nausea. Follow dosage instructions.

symptoms_tips.tip: If you're feeling fatigued, prioritize rest and sleep. Maintain a balanced diet and stay hydrated throughout the day.
symptoms_tips.food: Include energy-boosting foods like whole grains, lean proteins (chicken, fish), fruits, and vegetables in your meals. Avoid heavy, sugary snacks.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Fatigue can sometimes be linked to underlying health issues. Consult a healthcare provider for persistent fatigue or concerns.

symptoms_tips.tip: For a sore throat, gargle with warm saltwater and stay hydrated. Rest your voice and avoid irritants like smoking.
symptoms_tips.food: Eat soothing foods like warm soups, broths, or soft foods. Avoid spicy or acidic foods that can irritate the throat.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen (Tylenol) or throat lozenges may help. Consult a pharmacist or doctor for suitable options.

symptoms_tips.tip: For stomachaches, rest and avoid heavy meals. Consider applying a warm compress to ease discomfort.
symptoms_tips.food: Eat light, easy-to-digest foods like bananas, rice, applesauce, or plain toast (BRAT diet). Avoid greasy or spicy foods.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter antacids or pain relievers may help alleviate stomach pain. Follow dosage instructions carefully.

symptoms_tips.tip: If you have muscle pain, rest the affected area and apply ice or heat packs. Gentle stretching and massage may provide relief.
symptoms_tips.food: Include foods rich in magnesium and potassium like bananas, leafy greens, and nuts to support muscle function. Stay hydrated.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen (Advil/Motrin) or acetaminophen (Tylenol) may help reduce muscle pain. Follow dosage instructions carefully.

symptoms_tips.tip: A runny nose could be due to allergies or a cold. Use saline nasal sprays and stay hydrated. Rest and avoid irritants like smoke.
symptoms_tips.food: Drink warm liquids like herbal teas or broth to soothe a sore throat and stay hydrated. Avoid dairy products if you have excess mucus.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter antihistamines or decongestants may provide relief. Consult a pharmacist or doctor for suitable options.

symptoms_tips.tip: If you have diarrhea, stay hydrated with water, clear broths, or oral rehydration solutions. Avoid dairy, fatty foods, caffeine, and alcohol.
symptoms_tips.food: Eat bland, low-fiber foods like bananas, rice, applesauce, and toast (BRAT diet). Gradually introduce solid foods as symptoms improve.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter anti-diarrheal medications like loperamide (Imodium) may help control symptoms. Follow dosage instructions carefully.

symptoms_tips.tip: If you develop a rash, avoid scratching to prevent further irritation. Keep the affected area clean and dry. Identify and avoid potential allergens or irritants.
symptoms_tips.food: Focus on an anti-inflammatory diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and omega-3 fatty acids. Stay hydrated with water and herbal teas.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Topical corticosteroids or antihistamines may help relieve itching and inflammation. Consult a dermatologist for proper diagnosis and treatment.

symptoms_tips.tip: If you experience difficulty breathing, seek immediate medical attention. Practice relaxation techniques and avoid triggers like smoke or allergens.
symptoms_tips.food: Consume anti-inflammatory foods like turmeric, ginger, and leafy greens. Avoid heavy meals that may exacerbate breathing difficulties.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Depending on the cause, medications like bronchodilators or corticosteroids may be prescribed to alleviate symptoms. Follow medical advice closely.

symptoms_tips.tip: For joint pain, rest the affected joint and apply ice or heat packs. Gentle stretching and low-impact exercises may help alleviate stiffness.
symptoms_tips.food: Incorporate foods rich in omega-3 fatty acids (such as salmon, flaxseeds) and antioxidants (berries, spinach) to support joint health. Stay hydrated.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) may provide relief. Consult a healthcare provider for chronic or severe pain.

symptoms_tips.tip: To manage insomnia, establish a consistent sleep schedule and create a relaxing bedtime routine. Avoid stimulating activities and electronics before bed.
symptoms_tips.food: Choose sleep-promoting foods like almonds, turkey, kiwi, and whole grains. Limit caffeine and heavy meals close to bedtime.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Consult a healthcare provider for prescription sleep aids or supplements like melatonin if natural remedies are ineffective. Practice good sleep hygiene.

symptoms_tips.tip: For muscle soreness, rest the affected muscles and apply ice or heat packs. Gentle stretching and massages may help alleviate discomfort.
symptoms_tips.food: Consume foods rich in antioxidants (e.g., berries, spinach) and protein to support muscle recovery. Stay hydrated with water.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) can reduce pain and inflammation. Consult a healthcare provider for severe or persistent soreness.

symptoms_tips.tip: If you experience anxiety, practice relaxation techniques such as deep breathing or meditation. Maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise and adequate sleep.
symptoms_tips.food: Include foods rich in magnesium (e.g., leafy greens, nuts) and omega-3 fatty acids (e.g., salmon, chia seeds) to support mood regulation. Limit caffeine and alcohol.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Consider therapies like cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or medications like selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) under the guidance of a mental health professional.

symptoms_tips.tip: To relieve constipation, increase fiber intake through fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. Stay hydrated with water and herbal teas. Engage in regular physical activity.
symptoms_tips.food: Eat fiber-rich foods like prunes, bran cereal, beans, and broccoli. Avoid processed foods and dairy products if they contribute to constipation.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter laxatives (e.g., bulk-forming, stimulant) may provide short-term relief. Consult a healthcare provider for chronic or severe constipation.

symptoms_tips.tip: For dizziness, lie down in a safe place and rest until symptoms subside. Avoid sudden movements and stay hydrated with water or electrolyte drinks.
symptoms_tips.food: Eat small, frequent meals to stabilize blood sugar levels. Include foods rich in iron (e.g., spinach, red meat) and vitamin C (e.g., citrus fruits) to support circulation.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Consult a healthcare provider to determine the underlying cause of dizziness. Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery until symptoms resolve.

symptoms_tips.tip: For shortness of breath, sit upright and try to remain calm. Practice slow, deep breathing techniques. Use a fan or open a window for fresh air if possible.
symptoms_tips.food: Choose light, easy-to-digest foods to prevent further strain. Stay hydrated with water or herbal teas. Avoid heavy or large meals that can make breathing more difficult.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Inhalers or bronchodilators prescribed by a healthcare provider can help manage shortness of breath associated with conditions like asthma or COPD. Seek immediate medical attention for sudden or severe breathing difficulties.

symptoms_tips.tip: For itchy eyes, avoid rubbing them to prevent further irritation. Use artificial tears or eye drops to lubricate and soothe the eyes. Apply cool compresses over closed eyelids.
symptoms_tips.food: Include foods rich in vitamin A (e.g., carrots, spinach) and omega-3 fatty acids (e.g., salmon, flaxseeds) to support eye health. Stay hydrated with water and limit caffeine intake.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter antihistamine eye drops or oral antihistamines (e.g., loratadine) can help relieve itching caused by allergies. Consult a healthcare provider for persistent eye irritation.

symptoms_tips.tip: For tooth pain, rinse with warm salt water to reduce inflammation and relieve discomfort. Avoid very hot or cold foods that can trigger sensitivity. Use over-the-counter pain relievers as directed.
symptoms_tips.food: Choose soft, easy-to-chew foods like soups, yogurt, and mashed potatoes to minimize jaw movement. Avoid sugary foods and beverages that can worsen tooth sensitivity.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen can temporarily alleviate toothache pain. Consult a dentist for persistent or severe tooth pain.

symptoms_tips.tip: For sunburn relief, take a cool bath or shower to soothe the skin. Apply moisturizing lotion or aloe vera gel to hydrate and cool the affected area. Avoid further sun exposure.
symptoms_tips.food: Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated and aid skin recovery. Eat foods rich in antioxidants (e.g., berries, tomatoes) and vitamins C and E to promote healing.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help reduce pain and inflammation from sunburn. Use topical hydrocortisone cream for itching and discomfort.

symptoms_tips.tip: For minor burns, run cool water over the affected area for at least 10 minutes to cool the skin and reduce pain. Cover with a clean, non-stick bandage or cloth.
symptoms_tips.food: Consume foods rich in vitamin C (e.g., oranges, strawberries) and zinc (e.g., nuts, whole grains) to support skin healing. Drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Apply antibiotic ointment to prevent infection. Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help manage pain and inflammation. Seek medical attention for severe burns.

symptoms_tips.tip: For hay fever (allergic rhinitis), limit outdoor activities during peak pollen times. Keep windows closed and use air purifiers indoors. Rinse nasal passages with saline solution.
symptoms_tips.food: Include anti-inflammatory foods like apples, broccoli, and walnuts in your diet to support immune function. Drink plenty of fluids to thin mucus secretions.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter antihistamines (e.g., loratadine) or nasal corticosteroids can alleviate hay fever symptoms. Consult a healthcare provider for severe allergies or persistent symptoms.

symptoms_tips.tip: For eczema flare-ups, moisturize daily with emollients to hydrate and protect the skin barrier. Use mild, fragrance-free soaps and avoid hot baths. Wear soft, breathable fabrics.
symptoms_tips.food: Incorporate foods rich in omega-3 fatty acids (e.g., flaxseeds, salmon) and probiotics (e.g., yogurt) to support skin health. Stay hydrated with water and herbal teas.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Topical corticosteroids or calcineurin inhibitors can reduce inflammation and itching. Consult a dermatologist for severe or persistent eczema.

symptoms_tips.tip: For migraines, rest in a dark, quiet room and apply a cold compress to the forehead or neck. Practice relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation.
symptoms_tips.food: Eat magnesium-rich foods like almonds, spinach, and avocados to help prevent migraines. Stay hydrated with water and herbal teas. Avoid triggers like caffeine, alcohol, and processed foods.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers (e.g., acetaminophen, ibuprofen) or prescription medications like triptans can help alleviate migraine symptoms. Consult a healthcare provider for personalized migraine management.

symptoms_tips.tip: For bruises, apply a cold compress or ice pack wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling and pain. Elevate the injured area if possible. Rest and avoid strenuous activities.
symptoms_tips.food: Consume foods rich in vitamin K (e.g., kale, spinach) to support blood clotting and bruise healing. Include protein-rich foods like lean meats and beans to aid tissue repair.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help manage pain associated with bruises. Consult a healthcare provider for severe bruising or if bruises occur frequently.

symptoms_tips.tip: For hives (urticaria), apply cool compresses to the affected area to reduce itching and inflammation. Avoid scratching to prevent further irritation. Wear loose-fitting clothing.
symptoms_tips.food: Choose anti-inflammatory foods like berries, fatty fish (e.g., salmon), and leafy greens to support immune health. Stay hydrated with water and herbal teas.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) can help relieve hives symptoms. Consult a healthcare provider for severe or persistent outbreaks.

symptoms_tips.tip: For a sprained joint, rest and elevate the injured area to reduce swelling. Apply ice wrapped in a cloth for 15-20 minutes every few hours. Use a compression bandage to support the joint.
symptoms_tips.food: Consume foods rich in vitamin C (e.g., oranges, strawberries) and zinc (e.g., nuts, whole grains) to support tissue healing. Include protein sources like lean meats and beans for muscle repair.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help reduce pain and inflammation from a sprain. Consult a healthcare provider for severe sprains or if mobility is impaired.

symptoms_tips.tip: For back pain, rest in a comfortable position and apply ice or heat therapy to the affected area. Practice gentle stretching exercises and avoid lifting heavy objects.
symptoms_tips.food: Eat foods rich in calcium (e.g., dairy products, leafy greens) and vitamin D (e.g., fatty fish, fortified cereals) to support bone health and muscle function. Stay hydrated with water and herbal teas.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) can help alleviate back pain. Consult a healthcare provider for chronic or severe back pain.

symptoms_tips.tip: For sinus congestion, inhale steam from a bowl of hot water or use a humidifier to moisten nasal passages. Use saline nasal sprays or rinses to clear mucus.
symptoms_tips.food: Include spicy foods like chili peppers or horseradish to help thin mucus and relieve congestion. Drink plenty of fluids like water and herbal teas to stay hydrated.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter decongestants (e.g., pseudoephedrine) or nasal corticosteroids can reduce sinus congestion. Consult a healthcare provider for persistent or severe symptoms.

symptoms_tips.tip: For tooth sensitivity, use a soft-bristled toothbrush and desensitizing toothpaste. Avoid acidic foods and beverages that can wear down tooth enamel. Limit brushing vigorously and use gentle strokes.
symptoms_tips.food: Choose soft, non-acidic foods like yogurt, bananas, and oatmeal to minimize tooth sensitivity. Drink water or milk to neutralize acid in the mouth.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Desensitizing toothpaste containing potassium nitrate or fluoride can help alleviate tooth sensitivity. Consult a dentist for persistent or severe sensitivity.

symptoms_tips.tip: For bloating, eat smaller meals more frequently to prevent overloading the digestive system. Avoid carbonated drinks and chewing gum that can cause gas. Practice relaxation techniques to reduce stress.
symptoms_tips.food: Choose foods low in fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols (FODMAPs) such as leafy greens, bananas, and rice to reduce bloating. Drink herbal teas like peppermint or ginger.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter anti-gas medications like simethicone can help relieve bloating symptoms. Consult a healthcare provider for persistent or severe bloating.

symptoms_tips.tip: For heartburn, avoid trigger foods like spicy or acidic items. Eat smaller, more frequent meals and avoid lying down immediately after eating. Use pillows to elevate your head while sleeping.
symptoms_tips.food: Opt for low-acid foods like oatmeal, bananas, and whole grains to minimize heartburn. Drink plenty of water and avoid caffeine and alcohol.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter antacids (e.g., calcium carbonate) or acid reducers (e.g., ranitidine) can help relieve heartburn symptoms. Consult a healthcare provider for persistent or severe heartburn.

symptoms_tips.tip: For a stiff neck, apply a heating pad or warm compress to relax tense muscles. Gently stretch and rotate the neck to improve flexibility. Avoid sudden movements or activities that strain the neck.
symptoms_tips.food: Choose foods rich in magnesium (e.g., nuts, seeds) and potassium (e.g., bananas, potatoes) to support muscle relaxation and reduce stiffness. Stay hydrated with water and herbal teas.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) can help reduce neck pain and inflammation. Consult a healthcare provider for persistent stiffness or if accompanied by other symptoms.

symptoms_tips.tip: For acid reflux, eat smaller meals and avoid trigger foods like spicy, fatty, or acidic items. Stay upright after eating and avoid lying down immediately. Wear loose-fitting clothing to reduce pressure on the stomach.
symptoms_tips.food: Opt for non-acidic fruits like bananas, melons, and apples. Choose lean proteins like chicken or fish. Drink plenty of water and herbal teas.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter antacids (e.g., aluminum hydroxide) or acid reducers (e.g., proton pump inhibitors) can help manage acid reflux symptoms. Consult a healthcare provider for chronic reflux or severe symptoms.

symptoms_tips.tip: For jaw pain, apply a cold or warm compress to the affected area. Avoid chewing gum and hard foods that strain the jaw. Practice gentle jaw exercises and relaxation techniques.
symptoms_tips.food: Choose soft, easy-to-chew foods like yogurt, smoothies, and scrambled eggs to minimize jaw movement. Drink water and herbal teas to stay hydrated.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) can help alleviate jaw pain. Consult a healthcare provider for persistent or severe pain.

symptoms_tips.tip: For a dental abscess, rinse your mouth with warm salt water to reduce pain and swelling. Avoid very hot or cold foods and beverages. Use over-the-counter pain relievers as directed.
symptoms_tips.food: Choose soft, non-acidic foods like mashed potatoes, yogurt, and applesauce to minimize discomfort. Drink water or herbal teas to stay hydrated and flush out bacteria.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) can help manage pain from a dental abscess. Seek prompt dental care for evaluation and treatment.

symptoms_tips.tip: For pink eye (conjunctivitis), avoid touching or rubbing your eyes. Use warm compresses to reduce discomfort and remove crusty discharge. Wash hands frequently to prevent spreading.
symptoms_tips.food: Include foods rich in vitamin A (e.g., carrots, spinach) and vitamin C (e.g., oranges, strawberries) to support eye health and immune function. Drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter antihistamine or antibiotic eye drops can help treat pink eye symptoms. Consult a healthcare provider for severe or persistent symptoms.

symptoms_tips.tip: For an ear infection, apply a warm compress to the affected ear to reduce pain and discomfort. Avoid inserting objects into the ear canal. Rest in a comfortable position.
symptoms_tips.food: Choose soft, easy-to-chew foods like soups, yogurt, and applesauce to minimize jaw movement. Drink water or herbal teas to stay hydrated.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help manage ear pain. Antibiotic eardrops or oral antibiotics may be prescribed for bacterial infections. Consult a healthcare provider for evaluation and treatment.

symptoms_tips.tip: For vertigo, sit or lie down in a safe place until symptoms pass. Avoid sudden movements or changes in position. Use a support person or walking aid if needed.
symptoms_tips.food: Eat small, frequent meals to stabilize blood sugar levels. Include foods rich in magnesium (e.g., nuts, seeds) and vitamin B6 (e.g., bananas, chicken) to support balance and nerve function.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Medications like meclizine or diazepam may be prescribed by a healthcare provider to manage vertigo symptoms. Vestibular rehabilitation exercises can also be beneficial. Consult a professional for personalized treatment.

symptoms_tips.tip: For gout flare-ups, rest and elevate the affected joint to reduce swelling. Apply ice wrapped in a cloth for 15-20 minutes several times a day. Avoid alcohol and purine-rich foods.
symptoms_tips.food: Choose low-purine foods like cherries, berries, and low-fat dairy products to help lower uric acid levels. Stay hydrated with water and limit sugary beverages.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen can help reduce pain and inflammation during gout attacks. Consult a healthcare provider for long-term management and prevention.

symptoms_tips.tip: For gastroenteritis (stomach flu), rest and drink plenty of clear fluids to prevent dehydration. Gradually introduce bland, easy-to-digest foods as tolerated. Avoid dairy products, caffeine, and alcohol.
symptoms_tips.food: Start with BRAT foods (bananas, rice, applesauce, toast) and progress to soups, crackers, and lean proteins like chicken or tofu. Drink oral rehydration solutions to replace lost electrolytes.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter medications like bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol) can help alleviate symptoms of gastroenteritis. Consult a healthcare provider for severe or prolonged illness.

symptoms_tips.tip: For sun allergy (photosensitivity), avoid prolonged sun exposure, especially during peak hours (10 AM to 4 PM). Wear protective clothing, hats, and sunglasses. Use broad-spectrum sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher.
symptoms_tips.food: Include antioxidant-rich foods like berries, leafy greens, and nuts to support skin health. Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated and help flush out toxins.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Over-the-counter antihistamines (e.g., cetirizine) or corticosteroid creams can help relieve itching and inflammation from sun allergies. Consult a dermatologist for severe or persistent symptoms.

symptoms_tips.tip: For heat exhaustion, move to a cool, shaded area and rest. Remove excess clothing and use cool, wet cloths or take a cool shower to lower body temperature. Drink cool fluids like water or electrolyte drinks.
symptoms_tips.food: Eat small, light meals to aid digestion and energy recovery. Choose hydrating foods like watermelon, cucumber, and oranges. Avoid caffeine and alcohol, which can contribute to dehydration.
symptoms_tips.medicine: In cases of severe heat exhaustion, seek immediate medical attention. Use oral rehydration solutions or intravenous fluids to replace lost electrolytes. Avoid over-the-counter medications unless advised by a healthcare provider.

symptoms_tips.tip: To manage hypertension (high blood pressure), adopt a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products. Limit sodium intake and avoid processed foods high in salt. Engage in regular physical activity.
symptoms_tips.food: Include potassium-rich foods like bananas, oranges, and potatoes to help regulate blood pressure. Choose whole grains, lean proteins, and heart-healthy fats like olive oil and nuts.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Prescription medications like diuretics, ACE inhibitors, or calcium channel blockers may be prescribed to lower blood pressure. Monitor blood pressure regularly and consult a healthcare provider for personalized management.

symptoms_tips.tip: For insulin resistance, maintain a healthy weight through balanced nutrition and regular physical activity. Choose complex carbohydrates, lean proteins, and fiber-rich foods to stabilize blood sugar levels. Limit sugary beverages and processed foods.
symptoms_tips.food: Include high-fiber foods like beans, lentils, and whole grains to improve insulin sensitivity. Eat small, frequent meals to prevent blood sugar spikes. Drink water or herbal teas to stay hydrated.
symptoms_tips.medicine: Metformin or other medications prescribed by a healthcare provider may be used to manage insulin resistance. Monitor blood glucose levels and consult a professional for personalized treatment.

symptoms_tips.Tip: Keep the area clean and dry

symptoms_tips.Food: Vitamin C rich foods, Leafy greens
